X.T: Bridging the Efficiency Gap: Mastering LLM Caching for Next-Generation AI (Part 1)
X.ST: LLM caching refers to the process of storing and managing the intermediate computations and outputs generated by language models, allowing for rapid retrieval and reuse in subsequent queries or tasks. In this first part of a blog series, we'll explore the fundamental principles of LLM caching, delve into the various caching architectures and implementations that can be employed

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some cache architectures for LLM, classic and RAG. The cache key can be exact or semantic.

X.T: How I use LLMs ‚Äì neat tricks with Simon‚Äôs `llm` tool
X.ST: Earlier this year I co-authored a report about the direct environmental impact of AI, which might give the impression I‚Äôm massively anti-AI, because it talks about the signficant social and environmental of using it. I‚Äôm not. I‚Äôm (still, slowly) working through the content of the Climate Change AI Summer School, and I use it a fair amount in my job. This post shows some examples I use.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some positive feedback and some examples of usage of llm.

X.T: [Video Response] What Cloudflare's code mode misses about MCP and tool calling

X.T: How to Automate Anything with Python Inside Claude Desktop (Using MCP)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Implementing a very small and simple MCP Server using Python and uv.

X.T: Code execution with MCP: Building more efficient agents
X.ST: Direct tool calls consume context for each definition and result. Agents scale better by writing code to call tools instead. Here's how it works with MCP.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author suggest using MCP servers as code APIs rather than direct tool calls, and explain the advantages to do so: lesser use of context space, the data remains private (it is not seen by the LLM), persistence‚Ä¶

X.T: MCP vs RAG: Two Very Different Ways to Gain Context
X.ST: At first glance RAG and MCP seem similar. In practice, they solve very different problems and lead to very different system designs.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: I do not undestand this comparison between MCP and RAG: they do not have the same purpose, MCP is a protocol handling tools (anf other things), RAG is about using semantic search to complete the context. You could use a tool that performs semantic search, I would still call this RAG.
